transcript:
Patient: Over the past week, I had a few instances where I felt really down and frustrated with myself. One situation that stands out is when I received feedback on a paper I wrote for my PhD program. The professor pointed out several areas that needed improvement, and I immediately started thinking that I'm not cut out for this program and that I'll never be able to succeed.

Therapist: Thank you for sharing that, Noor. That's a great example of how a specific situation can trigger negative thoughts and emotions. In CBT, we call this the "cognitive model," which suggests that our thoughts, feelings, and behaviors are all interconnected. In this case, receiving critical feedback on your paper led to thoughts of self-doubt and inadequacy, which then resulted in feelings of sadness and frustration.

Patient: Yeah, that makes sense. It's like a chain reaction.

Therapist: Exactly. And often, these negative thoughts can be distorted or irrational, even though they feel very real in the moment. These distortions can contribute to feelings of depression and anxiety. Some common cognitive distortions include all-or-nothing thinking, overgeneralization, and jumping to conclusions.

Patient: I think I do that a lot – jumping to conclusions. Like with the paper, I immediately assumed that because I needed to make improvements, it meant I was a failure overall.

Therapist: That's a great insight, Noor. Jumping to conclusions is a common distortion, where we make assumptions without having all the facts. Another distortion that might be at play here is all-or-nothing thinking, where you see things in black-and-white terms – in this case, believing you're either a complete success or a total failure, with no in-between.

Patient: Yeah, I can see how that's not really accurate or helpful.

Therapist: You're right. The good news is that CBT can help you identify these distortions and learn to challenge and reframe them. By doing so, you can start to shift your thoughts and feelings in a more balanced, realistic direction.

Patient: That sounds really helpful. How would that work in this situation with my paper?

Therapist: One way to challenge these distortions is to look for evidence that supports or refutes them. For example, you could ask yourself, "Is it true that needing to improve my paper means I'm not cut out for the program?" You might consider other evidence, like the fact that you were accepted into the program, or times when you've received positive feedback on your work.

Patient: That makes sense. I guess I have had some successes, even if it doesn't always feel that way.

Therapist: Exactly. Another strategy is to consider alternative interpretations of the situation. Could there be other reasons why your professor pointed out areas for improvement, besides you being a failure? Perhaps they see your potential and want to help you grow, or they have high standards for all their students.

Patient: Yeah, I can see how that might be true. It's hard to remember that in the moment, though.

Therapist: That's completely understandable. It takes practice to start recognizing and challenging these distortions. As we continue working together, we'll explore more strategies for doing so, and you'll start to build those skills over time.
